text: all right so thank you so much it's uh pretty fantastic to be back connected at least virtually with
stanford when i was a grad student there i went to the pc seminars a lot so it's lovely to be giving one myself
um and so today i've decided uh to talk about design spaces for visualization um
and how to develop them and this is going to be a fairly methods oriented talk because i figured that a stanford
ats seminar audience would be interested in the sort of methodological underpinnings um particularly those that
you know go beyond just visualization and are more broadly applicable to hdi although i'm certainly going to be focused on visualization um in what i
say here so this term design spaces
well this has been a continuing theme in the visualization literature there was an early paper uh from mckinley and card
in 1997 called the structure of the information visualization design space
that might have actually been the first time i personally had run across that term used in this context um and then it continued uh there was a
nice paper in 2009 for example from job in elmquist exploring the design space
of composite visualizations if you have say multiple views um a nice one on a design space for
visualization tasks i'll also be talking some myself about uh design spaces for visualization texts
uh this was by schultz at all in 2013. uh really lovely paper just a few years ago from madison elliott and other folks
from the vision science research community on a design space of vision science methods for visualization research
so there's just quite a bit of these papers that propose design spaces
so what exactly are they um amusingly enough if you read a lot of
these papers they don't necessarily even define the term they just use this term and they often mean something in a rough
neighborhood all around a central point although they're sort of differing definitions my current one that i came
up with for this talk um gleaning from a few of uh of the existing ones is you know imposing a
systematic structure on some set of possibilities for a particular design
problem and uh the idea is you're trying to really capture the variables that are
central to design problem and the reason is you're trying to support some kind of reasoning about the set of choices that
you could pick in this design problem now what are people typically proposing
they're somehow delineating they're they're giving a structure of that space and a key part is that you have these
independent cross-cutting orthogonal ways to divide things up uh sometimes
people call these axes or dimensions or categories but the key ideas you've got places in which you can make independent
choices that have been uh and so you could you know enumerate the set of possibilities in a way that helps you
think now people call these many things i picked
the word design spaces for this talk um but people often call these taxonomies
sometimes they call them typologies and they quibble about the difference between those two they might call them classifications uh more general terms
like frameworks even a super general term like model um so you know in my own work i've called
these everything from design spaces to taxonomies to typologies to frameworks actually to classifications i've called
them all these things so as i talk through some different papers we've done in the past i might actually
switch between using these words that i'm basically all using
um so i i particularly like there was one from
david and elmquist which is a longer one a space within which to express design patterns that's another
uh sort of useful way to think about that now what are they for
so back in the cardinal mckinley paper um
their argument was that the reason they wanted to describe and analyze portions of the design space was to understand
the differences between designs and to suggest new so there was this idea of somehow think about how are things
different from each other how can you use this in a creative way
now in the elliott paper um i like their definition design spaces provide an actionable structure for systematically
reasoning about solutions so somehow there's this idea that it helps you do something
and then there's an interesting paper from pal ralph um that was actually published in the transactions on software engineering uh which has a lot
of very applicable advice for the hci and visualization communities uh that talks about methods for
both taxonomies and process theories where he argues that taxonomies increase cognitive efficiency and they support
inferences and the way that they do that is they help you to group together similar instances to let you reason
about that entire class rather than point by point reason about the instances of things in that design space
and i find that a very useful framing so how do you know
if a design space is helpful or good or better for a particular purpose than a previously published one or useful in
any way whatsoever how do you assess a design space that's a methodological question
um i'm particularly fond of a framework that michelle bonnie lafont talked about
and he had in mind assessing interfaces rather than design spaces or taxonomies but i've actually used it quite a bit
for taxonomies and i find it instructive to think about first of all descriptive
power does it give you the precision to distinguish what you care about within a
set of existing examples so can you use it to describe existing work in a way that helps you think does it you know
put things in the same category that really should be there and does it let you distinguish between when you need to
for the purpose of reasoning and exposition then there's evaluative power
so the ability to help you from a set of alternatives you're thinking about can help you decide which one might be
better for a particular purpose and then there's generative power does it help you create something new so can
you define exist can you describe existing can you evaluate possible and can you generate new those are three
interesting ways to think about the utility um and suitability of a design
space so how do we create them
well a really common way and actually a theme that runs through all of the ones i'm going to talk about myself today is
this idea that it would happen through an open coding process of source material
and um in case that's not clear when i say coding i don't mean programming i mean this qualitative analysis method
where you're coming up with a set of tags uh to describe um instances and
then you can use those to actually create this categorization it's typically a very iterative process a lot
of refinement uh sometimes it's called just thematic analysis a particular
framework for doing that's called grounded theory but i'm sort of going to think about all these although they have some you know
relatively subtle methodological differences these are all ways that i'm just going to talk about is open coding
some kind of source material um and we'll talk about different kinds of
source material and what that leads to of course you could go off and read research papers uh so in a literature
review then you're typically going to say well there's a bunch of theories out there maybe i'm going to synthesize a new one and you often want to compare a
new design space to previous ones or contextualize how yours fits in to the previous work in that
area and then there's a method of personal reflection which is you just sit down
and think um and of course any kind of an iterative open coding process does have a certain
amount of you sitting down and thinking um but uh having a design space that includes thinking broadly means you
don't just have to be constrained by the source material you're coding um it
really is something where you can think quite a bit about for the purposes that you're trying to create your design space what would be a useful way to
structure things again to help you think so i'm often going to call that reflective synthesis to really um
highlight the idea that you're often bringing many many things together in some deep sense with everything you've ever read or thought about
and that you're using as part of this creation process so broader than just open coding a specific corpus of source
material now what's interesting of course is you're not forced to do just one and
many real uh design space creation processes have these sort of interesting and complex combinations of those as
i'll get into so i'm going to actually talk through four major examples of creating a design
space one is really focused on a data type of um temporal data where the instances in
the design space are visual encodings of timelines so you know how do you actually make a visual
representation of a timeline one is more domain focused in the domain of genomic epidemiology um where the um
what we're thinking about is a design space for how would you actually make you know figures in research papers that
are helpful for researchers in this field i'll often abbreviate that as gen epi um
there's one in the domain of journalism which is not focused on visual encoding but focused on activities and tasks what
are people doing when they're wrangling or cleaning data and then finally there's a very domain agnostic one about a design space for
abstract tasks so i'll be talking through the similarities and differences in developing these design spaces
so let's jump in let's now start talking about timelines
so this is a paper um first off it was matt bremer who at the time was a pt student at ubc he's now at microsoft i'm
sorry at um tableau research um but this was done um in part while he was at microsoft research with uh bangtan lee
and natalie andres and benjamin bach was also at msr at the time
so this paper is called timelines revisited a design space and considerations for expressive storytelling and what we were thinking
about was what are some ways of creating timelines specifically for presentation
so there's often a split between exploratory and expository
or exploration and presentation in visualization and so we're specifically thinking of the context of presentation
so narrative intent something that's interesting there and we end up ended up proposing a
design space with three axes there was this representation one about you know
how are things actually looking are they linear do they wrap around radially is it a two-dimensional matrix like a grid
or a spiral or just any sort of um positional layout at all and then ideas
of scale if there's some idea of um you know is do you know that you've got a timeline that's purely chronological
um are you just interested in relative um differences between do you log scale it
is it just simply an order do you have some idea of durations in between not just points in time
and then finally for the layout is it just one thing have you faceted into you think of this as multiple views or
multiple timelines do they wrap around or do you have a combination of those
so if you think about this right there's five and five and four so sort of theoretically there could be up to a
hundred possibilities if we just enumerate them all um and we went through and thought for
these various combinations uh what we wanted to do is think about you know how are people actually using this what's
the narrative point um and when they're when you're looking at that what is the perceptual task that you're doing for
that particular visual coding right so here's one where we've got a radio layout and it's sequential and it's a single unified one
and we could go on and say well what about some other points in this design space what are you trying to achieve like compare sequence lengths between
these facets or here's one where instead of a circle we're looking at a spiral um so and it's
a slightly different perceptual task and you can think about information density um you know here's one where we've got a
grid so we went through and we did this characterization of both the narrative point and the
perceptual task that was at play in these visual encodings um and an interesting outcome is
they're not all good and in particular we propose of the hundred possibilities
we characterize 20 of them as what we called viable combinations and by viable we meant uh we had criteria of you know
purposeful you could actually use it for a particular narrative purpose interpretable in the sense that the
person viewing it could uh decode what you were trying to encode and then also generalizable it's not
tied to a very specific specific thing but it's a general way that you can encode uh this kind of temporal data
so we proposed that these 20 were really the viable ones out of the 100 possibilities
that the design space could afford so a key question how did we do this
um so the process we used to create this model was a sort of two-phase creation and
then analyzing so in order to create that design space what we did is we actually assembled a fairly extensive
corpus of source materials which was actual you know visually encoded timelines and we did this from say you
know infographics um you know visualization technique papers uh tools
that allowed people to create timelines so a really broad set of timelines um
and what we wanted to do was get something that was as uh as broad coverage as possible of the ways that
people would visually encode this temporal data and then we did an open coding process where we would look at
all these we would try to create groups think about what a good exemplar was and then think by actually sketching
alternatives with pen and paper you know what are some other ways that this data could have been represented that would make sense
um and of course a lot of iteration and the result was that three axis design space
that i've shown you and then there was this second phase where given that design space we then went in and
analyzed and thought of the combinatorics which ones do we think are reasonable because a very
interesting hint was in that entire corpus only 24 of those combinations even appeared
um and we actually made a judgment call about which ones we thought were a appropriate and suitable use of
visualization um and there was 20 of those that we actually thought were
wise choices for encoding so let's go back to that lens for
assessing and think about okay how did we argue that this design space was useful um
and uh so for descriptive power what we did is we actually stole an idea out of machine learning of gathering a second test set
so we thought of the corpus we used to create the design space as the training set although we didn't actually use
machine learning but we took this idea and we gathered a new set of timelines we had not looked at when we created the design
space and then we checked whether all of them were actually um covered in useful
ways in our design space axes and in fact they were all describable the whole set of
originals and the whole set of additional test set ones all of them could be described in this design space
and of that sort of aligning with our take about what was viable we thought that 253 of those were matching that set
that we thought were wise choices out of the 100 uh theoretical combinatorial possibilities
now in terms of generative power how did we actually show that well we took those
20 viable designs and we instantiated a uh authoring software um
what we call sandbox software just to let people play with things and so we implemented that and particularly having
animated transitions between each of them so that if you were trying to do something like create a you know
storytelling video uh you could and so we then tried to find a representative set of datasets that covered a lot of
the possibilities and actually used the toolbox to create a bunch of these uh timeline designs and we actually with
the paper had seven full videos going through a timeline and telling stories with it using this authoring software
that was built around this design space uh and so that was how we tried to show its generative power is that we could
actually build something to let people use it um and there's a nice adoption story um
this was both uh open sourced and it's uh still up and running if you want to play with it at timelinestorytaylor.com
and that's a free browser version and it was also integrated into the microsoft product power bi
as an add-on so that was a nice way of getting stuff from research directly into people's hands
okay so that was a little story about timelines and that's data type now now let me tell
you a story about a domain about genomic epidemiology jen abbey for short because that's a lot of syllables
um and this was work done in collaboration with uh anakrasen who at the time was a
phd student at uh ubc um she's now at tableau research and jen gardy uh who's
uh at the time was ubc professor she's now at the gates foundation uh working on malaria um and at the time both of
them actually uh were part-time affiliated with the bc center for disease control um so they had a deep domain knowledge
in uh the catholic immunology in particular and so this gevit project was actually
both proposing a method and presenting a typology created with that method
so let's take a look at that so we proposed was a particular method
for creating typologies that was really a mixed methods approach where we're mixing qualitative and quantitative
approaches in a very deliberate way and so it was a sort of multi-phased process that was built around the idea
that you'd have some big corpus of research papers and you could do an automatic literature
analysis phase and then based on the results of that you could do visualization analysis that makes a
qualitative first phase followed by a quantitative phase so let me talk you through that
um this particular typology we developed which we called gevit for genomic epidemiology visualization typology um
in the first phase the analysis phase we would actually go in and create clusters so we would use nlp techniques to create
topic clusters and then we would use those for stratified sampling to make sure that we actually had coverage
across all of these clusters um and so we used a random stratified sampling approach for
taking for actually being able to sample articles and then extract figures from those
sample articles and then go in and do open coding on what are they doing in those figures um
so and i'll talk you through what the actual three axes were give it in just a sec
so what we called this was a not just a design space but a domain prevalence design space
so you know the big picture is that the literature analysis could be used to address this question of why are they
researching it what are you know the clusters the topics that these papers are about
and then the visual adjacent analysis could first say how are they visualizing and then for each of these how many
examples are there so in particular when we had this idea that you could say
well in infectious disease genomic epidemiology research articles we could use text mining to find both the topics
that just came out of pure text mining and also any uh concepts that domain
experts thought would be interesting to make sure to be able to sample for and then we could do that random
stratified sampling take the output of that try to describe what the elements are
and then quantify and that because we're actually trying to be very careful and systematic about coverage doing that
kind of account would be a reasonable thing to do even though often in a purely qualitative
analysis process we wouldn't normally try to argue that counts are meaningful in this one because of the care taken to
do that stratified sampling we do think that in fact it's a reasonable thing to do
so just to sort of click by the numbers i'm not going to walk through all these numbers but i want to point out why do we have to be systematic it's because
when you start out and you do a literature search on pubmed you get 18 000 articles and you're not going to you
know open code all of those so after we did the clustering and removed articles that didn't fit into clusters and then
we removed the articles without the human pathogens and then removed sort of you know very small topics we ended up
with a total of 18 of these topic clusters that turned out to map very clearly into particular pathogens that
cause diseases and then other a priori concepts like surveillance or
all kinds of things like that that the domain experts decided were useful so they had these two sort of cross-cutting ways to have um clusters
to sample and what they ended up doing uh at the end of that sampling process that i'm not going to go into in exact
detail here with a couple hundred papers and those are something where you can extract all the figures so that was
800 figures which is a lot but nowhere near the you know tens of thousands that
we would have had so what was the design space actually
going to look like we ended up saying that one interesting thing was what chart types are they using uh so common
charts and you know relational charts like nodes and graphs temporal charts spatial charts a lot of trees
phylogenetic and otherwise a lot of very specific charts used in genomics um and
a collection of others and so one of the one of the um axes of this design space
was well what chart type are they using but then another axis was and how are they combining it
are they doing any sort of spatial alignment either horizontally or vertically or are they showing relationships
between these multiple charts with something like matching color coding or matching shape coding um are they using
the visualization technique of small multiples to have the same visual encoding across a bunch of disjoint data
sets or did they just slam two figures side by side as subfigures maybe just because
they had space constraints in their article and even though they're next to each other they don't actually have any explicit alignment at all it's just sort
of more of a grab bag and since we were doing this idea of uh stratified sampling then we were able to actually
come up with counts of noting uh numbers that we thought would be representative of what people were doing
and finally the third axis is the idea that they didn't just take something that they might have automatically generated they often added things on to
that uh sometimes with tools but often manually so and what's interesting from a
visualization person's point of view is it's very common to talk about point in line area as types of marks that can
convey information which you can then visually encode with channels like size and shape and color but they did this
with text too they did a remarkable amount of using fonts and colors and even font face to try to express
categorizations um and uh so that was a very uh somewhat surprising from a sort
of visualization dogma point of view of just how much they were trying to use the text properties itself to encode
additional information so just to give make this a bit more concrete uh here's an example of a
figure from a published article and from the literature analysis we knew that it was a particular pathogen in
this case enterococcus and then from the chart point of view we can say well there was a tree and there was a heat
map and one of these sort of one-dimensional heat maps we call category stripe in between and they were spatially
aligned where it meant something that they had shared horizontal position and then there were a bunch of these
other marks they actually added branches between two different trees to show uh where those species were the same
they um actually used color coding to try to show these groupings within the tree they added some of these annotation
marks so let's think about what the this the
assessment of this one was um from a descriptive power point of view it really did provide a common language
which really hadn't been there before it wasn't clear what kinds of visualizations people were using in this domain
and we were able to notice that aha because we saw what they actually did
not just what the tool supported that there was a huge amount of stuff they were doing that was not supported by any current tools once we saw the breadth of
what people were doing in terms of evaluative power we could see there are some shortfalls um you
know from a visualization point of view perhaps over using you know text as a way to convey uh information
perceptually and in terms of generative power in some follow-up work we did do the idea of
trying to actually build it to try to take that design space and instantiate it in this case as a recommender system
so using this idea of domain prevalence and design space accounts to build something um that would automatically
recommend the visual encoding for particular uh combination of data sets uh people are curious that's hot off the
presses just got accepted into tvcg and we'll present that it is in the fall
and there's a link to that all right that was the second one what about a
third one how did you think about design spaces in data wrangling so this is joint work with steve kasich
who's currently still a phd student at ubc and charles barrett uh who at the moment is a postdoc with me here at ubc
so this is an actionable framework for multi-table data wrangling from an artifact study of computational
journalism so what do i mean by that all right this idea of data wrangling
sometimes this is called data cleaning or um data cleansing or any of these um
things of you take the data set you have to do something before you can actually do the kind of analysis you had in mind
now journalists do a lot of data wrangling um it's a general idea in data science but journalists in particular
especially with the advent of a lot of visual data journalism are doing a lot of data wrangling and what's interesting about it is they
show their work a lot of that wrangling in many contexts is done behind the scenes in all kinds
of domains but the journalists actually tell you what they did um they literally
call it the nerd box that's the internal name for when you have that little sidebar or snippet that says well here's
the methods we use here's the link to how we did the analysis and so they actually publish their code
they will publish data wrangling code in repositories whether github or observable or there's many many hundreds
of these out there because there's a journalistic value of transparency editorial transparency so that the
public can actually see how you came to the conclusions you did or a colleague could reproduce that um so there's this
culture of transparency which makes it a really interesting target for wrangling research because we can see what people
are actually doing so what we did in this this is what we're calling a technical observation
study following some terminology from that paul ralph paper i mentioned at the very beginning um
where the artifact that we're coding is journalist software scripts so
um to really understand what are journalists doing journalists who code how are they data wrangling um we had a
process for trying to make sure we had good coverage of all of these repos and then we did open coding of the software
scripts that did the wrangling we also ended up creating sketches of
how the data flowed between the different tables um because it ended up being so unexpectedly complex
so this was these were not things we found in the repos these were our interpretation of what the code in the
repos were actually doing and the result of that process um was
very detailed taxonomy of how data wrangling is done in computational journalism and then we had a second
phase where we wanted to say given these very bottom-up taxonomies how does this align with previous work in the area and
let's make sure that our tags for our codes in our open code set are actually harmonized with this previous uh work
and where are their differences where do the journalists do something which hasn't been talked about by generic data
wrangling uh papers so then we adapted that taxonomy and
iterated and refined it even more until that was finalized and then said but
those taxonomies they have great descriptive power but they don't seem to have much generative power can we come
up with something that would be more uh helpful in letting us build a tool to
address some of the pain points and so there was this reflective synthesis process where we re-characterized in a design space that
was much more suited for having generative power
so i'm not going to go into a great detail on here i'll just mention that we looked at a total of well over a
thousand repos and using a set of inclusion criteria and then narrowed that down to a set of a couple hundred
that were suitable and then we sampled from that multiple times keeping uh some diversity criteria into account trying
to make sure we had a range of journalists uh large newsrooms small newsrooms
um and so we ended up open coding 50 of those in great detail um to generate uh
the first level taxonomies and then went into this alignment process um and had a taxonomy with a total of
165 codes and then created this much more concise framework and checked it against the first set of taxonomies
so what are these um i'm not going to walk you through every single detail of them but at the high level there's
actions taken by journalists uh and there's processes that was our interpretation of what we thought they
were doing uh and we really wanted to distinguish between those uh because one was um interpretive and one was much
more descriptive and this had a lot of power this was uh quite detailed it went down five levels
to some very detailed descriptions a total of 165 codes in that code set across both
so that was great for description but it wasn't really something that we
could use to build tools around and so that's when we started thinking well what what is interesting here what are
the points of divergence and the sheer number of tables that journalists were using was jaw dropping these are all
some of these uh diagrams trying to show what was happening with data flow between tables there's a lot of arrows
here and uh so we found you know there were some quite relatively simple ones but
also some very very complex ones and it wasn't well supported by any kind of interacting interactive wrangling tools
like you know something like uh trifacta or tableau prep or that kind of thing these weren't scaling to the sheer
number of tables and the ways that people were chopping them up and shoving them together
so we thought well how could we think about a framework that would let you build a tool to support this kind of stuff much
more uh cleanly than anything we saw before so we proposed a design space
with two axes one is focused on the kind of thing they're doing is it a table or a row
or a column and one was focused on essentially what kinds of operations are they doing in
terms of um the number of things in and the number of things out so creation is where you go from nothing
to something deletion is where you go from one thing to know things and then any kind of a one-to-one transformation or any kind of
a separation from one thing into many are combining many back down into one and that actually gave us a really
concise and quite actionable design space that we thought had suitable generative power for thinking about this
and uh so that was an example where we really needed to go from one design space to
another where we thought differently about descriptive versus generative power so that we had something we thought we could build a tool around
then we did want to make sure that this new space actually covered all the cases of the actions taxonomy and in fact it did
spoiler alert so
let me just go back to this one moment um we haven't actually built this tool yet we do hope to in fact i'm actively
looking uh for um any sort of journalist partners who'd be interested in working with us
we've already talked to the folks uh behind open refine and we really are interested in building kind of a
multi-table wrangling framework um and so i'm actively looking for collaboration partners as we go from
this investigation to actually doing tool building quite soon
okay so now for our last one let's think a little bit about abstract tasks so
this multi-level typology of abstract visualization tasks was joint work with matt bramer when he was still a phd
student people have thought a lot about tasks in visualization and the need to somehow in
a domain-independent way say what are people doing um and sometimes they call them tasks or
goals or intentions or objectives or activities or interactions they use a lot of different words that are all sort of in the same general ballpark
a lot of these are quite low level right like a retrieve of value or you know find maximum value very very low level
operations and some of them are incredibly high level like integrate insight um
and what we argued was there was really a gap between these that needed addressing about how to go from you know
between low and high so a multi-level taxonomy to help you along and there have been some work in that
area but but not nearly as much so
what we did was a process where we went very deep very deep into the literature and also very deep into reading and
thinking so we did a combination of open coding of the literature where we read
dozens and dozens of papers grabbed all of the words they used to describe any of these tasks and then tried to come up
with something that was integrated across all of them but suitable for a visualization context so a lot of
reading and thinking rearranging trying to group trying to simplify and iterating
where what we were open coding was what had been proposed both in actual taxonomies and any other research papers
that address these questions of abstract tasks we did a lot of this there was a lot of
iteration you can see some physical whiteboards all kinds of digital whiteboards where we went through and came up with many many possibilities
as we finally ended up with a quite concise taxonomy of 27 terms that we
thought suitably covered a big hunk of the visualization task design space
in that final one we had three axes and the two really well developed ones were why and how and there was also a sort of
um stub what space of just thinking that there'd be data as input and data as output uh as possibilities in a sequence
of tasks but we're really quite focused on the why and the how
now what we also did in this somewhat heroic table um is this is a lookup table where
we mapped for every of our 27 terms we said exactly where in the previous work
that term or or what we considered synonyms were used so this was actually across 30 previous taxonomies plus 20
more papers that went deep into these questions of abstract tasks so for example navigate you know a bunch
of the previous work just used the word navigate but some used words like pan or detail on demand or drill down or any of
a number of other words that we consider to be in this category and so this was direct references to all those papers
or compare right some previous taxonomies actually used the word compare others would use words like
discriminate or associate for example so this was really to try to give a very
clear connection to this rich rich vein of previous work and
let people understand how what we were proposing connected in detail to all of that
previous work now we didn't just do this sort of
bottom-up uh approach of um looking at uh what other taxonomies had proposed we
also looked at a lot of theoretical lenses which was more of a top-down thing so one of the things we're
thinking of for example was don norman's stages of action heidi lam's extension of that to add
ideas of the gulf of goal formation uh the literature on distributed cognition and sense making from park and other
places play theory um some of my own previous work on what i call the nested
model of visualization that really distinguish between thinking about things at a domain specific level
abstracting that in terms of both the data and the task and then and visual encoding and interaction techniques and
finally the level of algorithm design and this was deliberately made to fit
into those middle two levels that focusing on the why of of tasks and the what of data and
connecting that into the how of visual encoding and interaction techniques
so thinking about that in terms of these again three ways to assess um we found that we had something with a
lot of descriptive power it was possible to analyze a lot of existing interfaces in terms of
sequences of these tasks which really helped us think about both the eventual ends and also the means to that end when
you decomposed what was going on in visualization systems it also was really targeted at having
generative power of when you were in the early stages of problem-driven work uh that kind of work is often called design
studies in the visualization literature where when you're in the process of trying to abstract from domain specific stuff to a
layer that's agnostic to what domain it came from when you're doing that requirements gathering that's really where we wanted people to be able to
focus um and then for evaluative power we did explicitly see this as something that
would let you have a code set if you were doing field studies or maybe a task set if you're proposing what people
would do in a lab study and to be able to connect that with this really voluminous previous work um so to
possibly get better external validity for any kind of a formal experiment what's really gratifying is the
community has responded with adopting uh this framework so there's been hundreds of people who have used this for all
three of descriptive and generative and evaluative purposes uh so that's been really heartening to see

follow-on paper um from just a few years ago where we thought not just about

these problem-driven design study papers uh because there's been quite a corpus of those published um in the years

so i've talked about a number of different design spaces and let me think about similarities and differences
so we've had these four timelines gen epi wrangling tasks
now in all of them there was some amount of open coding of source material either actual visual encodings of timelines or
figures from research papers or software from repositories or tasks that were extracted from research papers
now there was also different strategies for sampling in some we had to assemble the corpus and that was part of the
intellectual contribution and then we went through and used the entire corpus in some we had this huge space for
example you know research papers in uh genomic epidemiology where there's tens of thousands and then we had a very
systematic approach of stratified random sampling of these clusters so that we
could actually then do some quantification because we were being systematic um in others we had something
much more qualitative like in the wrangling study uh we did have this idea of having different criteria for
diversity of which of those repos we would open code to try to make sure we got reasonable coverage and hit
theoretical saturation and then with the abstract tasks we weren't trying to sample we were trying to see everything we were trying to grab
it all and put it all together in one unified way so pretty different sampling strategies
there was reflective synthesis in three out of the four but it happened at different phases in some it was an early
phase thing where even from the beginning we were doing a combination of open coding and thinking about what we
thought would be something useful whereas with the wrangling one we did that late where we assembled an entire
taxonomy with the truly brought them up process and then thought about could we come up with something different that would
actually give us generative power so it was a late stage reflective synthesis
in terms of you know connecting with previous research literature we basically just mined that for some
source material for the timelines project we didn't explicitly do a viz research
search although we were certainly informed by that as part of the genetic project and then we very explicitly
tried to make sure we connected to that research what i'll call a light mapping pass with the wrangling project and a
really deep and thorough mapping path to that previous work in the task project
so thinking about descriptive power um we tried validation against a test set for the timeline project we had this
really systematic method um that gave us a lot of very comprehensive coverage for the genepi project
we had this really high precision descriptive power that allowed us to find where the other work that wasn't
specific to journalists diverged from what that group did and then we had this um quite widespread
adoption of the task taxonomy showing that there was quite a bit of descriptive power in that one
now for generative power for two of these we built one we built in the paper itself one we built in in implementation
in a follow-up paper uh the third we plan to build um so this idea that you could use a design space as the basis
for some sort of software implementation um and then there was quite a bit of usage of the abstract cast technology
when people were doing these sort of um design focused visualization projects after that was published
now what i think is interesting is thinking about the descriptive versus the generative power so in one in the timelines we had
something where we used analysis to characterize a subset uh to give us more generative power and with gen epi we use
the exactly the same ones we didn't have this distinction and it was a very detailed fine-grained one
whereas with the wrangling paper we didn't take a subset we actually developed something completely new to
get generative power and then with the abstract tasks again it was the same but it was a very concise one so we had generative power
in mind from the beginning as we thought about those so these different um approaches and we really focused much
more on evaluative power really only in that last one and that brings me to discussing the
assessment what i find is i always think about generative and descriptive power and i find sometimes it's less easy to
think about when could you distinguish the power to evaluate alternatives from the power to generate new or describe
existing and i find often in my own thinking that's less obviously a third category than the descriptive versus
generative so i want to come back as a wrap up to this thinking about well how do we
assess taxonomies and to sort of frame this in the larger context of different
kinds of theories so for example ben schneiderman who's designing the ui book talks about
descriptive theories explanatory theories you can imagine taxonomies possibly fitting into that but
definitely this idea of a prescriptive theory or predictive theory that's not what a taxonomy or a design space is
trying to do and i really like the way that paul ralph talked about it in this really
intriguing paper that i'm going to encourage folks in hci and viz to really dive into it's quite recent
and um he talks about different kinds of theories as theories for understanding where you organize something into useful
categories that's exactly a taxonomy versus process theories where you think
about how something happens uh ralph argues these are often sort of augmented taxonomies so it's useful to think about
them together and he's really separating them from theories of variance explanations of why
something happens where you've got some sort of causality relationship these are the kinds of things you can use for prediction and that's not what
taxonomies and design spaces are typically all about and so since we're not doing that kind
of predictive thing this has implications for how do we assess taxonomies these are different criteria
than the bodily phone three ones um and he goes through and discusses essentially which criteria he thinks are
relevant for taxonomies like parsimony transferability outside the corpus you made it from ideas of theoretical
saturation to really make sure you've extracted everything you can sometimes questions like is it useful is
it original does it resonate or is it perhaps not necessarily resonating by being something um surprising and new
can you test it these are all interesting but are not necessarily required and then specifically argues
that questions like statistical generalizability and things like construct or internal or conclusion
validity those are the kinds of questions you ask of predictive theories like variance series but not for the
kind of stuff we're doing with design spaces and taxonomies so i find this a useful way to guide thinking and i
wonder if it's a field we could really make these distinctions and think about these criteria in addition to
descriptive and generative and evaluative power so that i'd like to wrap things up um if
